user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_CopyToReturnValue:
```c
void UT_Stub_CopyToReturnValue(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const void *BufferPtr, size_t BufferSize)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);
    if (StubPtr != NULL)
    {
        /* If the size does not match, there is a bug */
        if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize != BufferSize)
        {
            UtAssert_Abort("Size mismatch in setting return value");
        }
        else
        {
            memcpy(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, BufferPtr, BufferSize);
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position = BufferSize;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Stub_CopyToReturnValue:
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are used in the provided function body. The code consists of standard C constructs (function definition, pointer parameters, conditional statements, struct member access, calls to memcpy and a project assertion function, and use of NULL and size_t). There are no occurrences of known compiler-specific extensions or keywords (for example: __attribute__, __asm, __extension__, typeof, __builtin_*, inline-asm, pragma directives, or other vendor-specific keywords) in the shown fragments.

The remaining symbols that might look nonstandard (UT_EntryKey_t, UT_StubTableEntry_t, cpuaddr, uint32, UT_EntryData_t) are typedefs or project-defined types shown only by name; a typedef name itself is not a language extension. Without documentation showing that identifiers such as cpuaddr or uint32 are actually compiler-provided, undocumented built-ins or language extensions, they cannot be flagged under MISRA C Rule 1.2. Therefore no fragments are reported for further investigation.
